Gokaldas Exports Limited is a company that delivered a profit before tax of ` 159 Crore. It has made capital investment of ` 143 Crores towards the modernization and upgradation of existing machines, capacity creation, and new projects. It completed the acquisition of Atraco entities at an investment of ` 373 Crores and acquisition of Matrix Design with an investment of ` 323 Crores. After the acquisition of the two companies through a combination of debt and equity, the Company had a net debt of ` 336 Crore as of March 31, 2024. Subsequently, the Company raised equity capital of ` 600 Crore through Qualified Institutional Placement (QIP) in April 2024, which has helped the Company to turn net cash positive. The long-term strategic objective is to create value for its shareholders, employees, and business partners by delivering quality products, and excellence in customer relationships, and will continue to remain focused on these initiatives for sustainable profitable growth.

Liabilities of uncertain timing or amount. Provisions are recognized when the Company has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a past event, it is probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation and a reliable estimate can be made of the amount of the obligation.

A possible obligation that arises from past events whose existence will be confirmed by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events beyond the control of the Company or a present obligation that is not recognised because it is not probable that an outflow of resources will be required to settle the obligation. A contingent liability also arises in extremely rare cases where there is a liability that cannot be recognised because it cannot be measured reliably.

Stock-in-trade refers to the inventory of goods purchased for resale by Gokaldas Exports Limited. Purchases of stock-in-trade were not present in FY24 but amounted to INR 85.27 lakhs in FY23.

Inventories refer to the total value of work-in-progress and finished goods (readymade garments) held by Gokaldas Exports Limited. There was a decrease of INR 3,000.23 lakhs in FY24 compared to an increase of INR 12,324.37 lakhs in FY23.

Employee benefit expenses include salaries, wages, contributions to provident and other funds, share-based payment expenses, gratuity expenses, and staff welfare expenses incurred by Gokaldas Exports Limited. These expenses increased from INR 61,901.53 lakhs in FY23 to INR 70,638.29 lakhs in FY24.

Finance costs include interest charges on Indian rupee packing credit loans, Indian rupee loans from banks, bill discounting, lease liabilities, bank charges, and other borrowing costs incurred by Gokaldas Exports Limited. These costs decreased slightly from INR 2,535.48 lakhs in FY23 to INR 2,416.43 lakhs in FY24.

Depreciation and amortization expense includes the depreciation of property, plant, and equipment, amortization of other intangible assets, and amortization on right-of-use assets. These expenses increased from INR 7,075.33 lakhs in FY23 to INR 7,879.38 lakhs in FY24.

Other expenses include consumption of stores, spares, other manufacturing expenses, water, electricity, fuel charges, clearing, forwarding, freight, rental charges, legal and professional fees, traveling and conveyance, rates and taxes, insurance, repairs and maintenance, telephone and internet expenses, payments to auditors, sitting fees, corporate social responsibility expenditure, provision for doubtful debts, and miscellaneous expenses. These expenses increased from INR 15,091.63 lakhs in FY23 to INR 17,344.25 lakhs in FY24.

The Companies Act, 2013, is the Indian law that governs company incorporation, regulation, and management. It mandates that companies meeting certain thresholds spend at least 2% of their average net profit for the preceding three financial years on corporate social responsibility (CSR) activities.
Corporate Social Responsibility Committee is a committee formed by Gokaldas Exports Limited as per the Companies Act, 2013, to oversee and manage the company's CSR activities.

CSR refers to Corporate Social Responsibility, which includes activities related to education and healthcare as specified in Schedule VII of the Companies Act, 2013. Gokaldas Exports Limited's CSR expenditure increased from INR 103.55 lakhs in FY23 to INR 235.24 lakhs in FY24.

Property, plant, and equipment (PPE) refers to the tangible assets held by Gokaldas Exports Limited for use in production or supply of goods or services, for rental to others, or for administrative purposes. There was a net gain on disposal of PPE of INR 605.03 lakhs in FY23, but no such gain in FY24.

Current Ratio is a financial ratio that measures a company's ability to pay its short-term obligations with its current assets. The Current Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 2.01 in FY24 and 2.25 in FY23.

Debt Equity Ratio is a financial ratio that measures a company's leverage by comparing its total debt to its total equity. The Debt Equity Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 0.08 in FY24 and 0.05 in FY23.

Debt Service Coverage Ratio is a financial ratio that measures a company's ability to cover its debt obligations with its earnings. The Debt Service Coverage Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 0.40 in FY24 and 0.66 in FY23.

Return on Equity Ratio is a financial ratio that measures a company's profitability by comparing its net income to its shareholders' equity. The Return on Equity Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 0.15 in FY24 and 0.22 in FY23.

Inventory Turnover Ratio is a financial ratio that measures how many times a company's inventory is sold and replaced over a period. The Inventory Turnover Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 3.05 in FY24 and 3.25 in FY23.

Trade Receivables Turnover Ratio is a financial ratio that measures how efficiently a company collects its receivables. The Trade Receivables Turnover Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 11.36 in FY24 and 18.11 in FY23.

Trade Payable Turnover Ratio is a financial ratio that measures how efficiently a company pays its suppliers. The Trade Payable Turnover Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 9.62 in FY24 and 10.30 in FY23.

Net Capital Turnover Ratio is a financial ratio that measures how efficiently a company uses its capital to generate sales. The Net Capital Turnover Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 1.91 in FY24 and 2.77 in FY23.

Net Profit Ratio is a financial ratio that measures a company's profitability by comparing its net profit to its revenue. The Net Profit Ratio for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 7.67% in FY24 and 8.03% in FY23.

Return on Capital Employed is a financial ratio that measures a company's profitability by comparing its earnings before interest and taxes to its capital employed. The Return on Capital Employed for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 30.85% in FY24 and 35.18% in FY23.
Return on Investment is a financial ratio that measures the profitability of an investment. The Return on Investment for Gokaldas Exports Limited was 18.19% in FY24 and 23.35% in FY23.
MSKA & Associates is the auditor for Gokaldas Exports Limited.

A financial ratio calculated as Profit for the period/year divided by Average total Equity. The average total equity is calculated as (opening total equity+closing total equity)/2. For Gokaldas Exports Limited, this ratio decreased due to an increase in the equity base from the acquisition of Matrix Clothing through preferential allotment of shares in March 2024, from which the yield is yet to occur.

A financial ratio calculated as Cost of goods sold divided by Average Inventory. The average inventory is calculated as (opening inventory+closing inventory)/2. For Gokaldas Exports Limited, this ratio was lower due to increased inventory holding with a lower revenue base, as inventory was built up to meet subsequent months' production.

A financial ratio calculated as Total sale of finished goods divided by Average trade receivables. The average trade receivables is calculated as (opening trade receivables+closing trade receivables)/2. For Gokaldas Exports Limited, this ratio increased due to year-end shipments as opposed to lower revenue, resulting in lower receivable turns.

A financial ratio calculated as Total Purchases divided by Average trade payables. The average trade payable is calculated as (opening trade payable+closing trade payable)/2. For Gokaldas Exports Limited, there was no major variance given the higher payables at the end of the year.

A financial ratio calculated as Revenue from operations divided by Average total Equity. The average total equity is calculated as (opening total equity+closing total equity)/2. For Gokaldas Exports Limited, this ratio was lower due to a significant increase in equity following the preferential allotment of shares to Matrix Clothing for acquisition.

A financial ratio calculated as Profit for the period/year (PAT) divided by Revenue from operations. For Gokaldas Exports Limited, this ratio decreased due to lower profit after tax in relation to a decrease in sales of finished goods.

A financial ratio calculated as (Profit Before Tax + Finance cost excluding interest on ROU liabilities - Fair value gain on mutual fund investments - Interest on Bank Deposits) divided by ((Total Assets - ROU Assets - investment in mutual funds - Fixed Deposit - Investments relating to acquired entities )-(Current Liabilities-Current borrowings-Current lease liabilities)). For Gokaldas Exports Limited, this ratio decreased due to lower earnings and increased capital investments relating to modernization/upgradation of machinery and capacity expansion.

A financial ratio calculated as Earnings before interest, depreciation and taxes (Profit Before Tax + Finance cost + Depreciation) divided by Average total assets. The average total assets is calculated as (opening total assets+closing total assets)/2. For Gokaldas Exports Limited, this ratio decreased due to lower earnings before interest and tax, a decrease in sales of finished goods, and an increase in capital investment to complete new business acquisitions.

The Income Tax Act, 1961 is the primary legislation governing income tax in India, under which Gokaldas Exports Limited claims tax exemptions and deductions subject to prescribed conditions. It also stipulates the payment of income tax based on regular income tax or Minimum Alternate Tax (MAT), as mentioned in the standalone financial statements.

Minimum Alternative Tax (MAT) is the minimum tax payable by companies in India, as per the Income Tax Act, 1961. If the regular income tax is less than MAT, the company is liable to pay MAT. MAT paid in excess can be carried forward for fifteen years.

Section 115BAA is a section inserted in the Income Tax Act, 1961, allowing domestic companies an option to pay tax at a lower rate of 22% (effective rate of 25.168%) subject to certain conditions. MAT is inapplicable for companies opting for this lower tax rate.

Market risk is the risk of loss in future earnings, realisable fair values, or cash flows due to changes in the price of a financial instrument, influenced by interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates, equity price fluctuations, and market liquidity as described in Gokaldas Exports Limited's Annual Report FY23-24.

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in market interest rates. Gokaldas Exports Limited manages this risk by maintaining a balanced portfolio of fixed and variable rate loans and borrowings.

Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of an exposure will fluctuate because of changes in foreign exchange rates. Gokaldas Exports Limited manages this risk by hedging transactions expected to occur within a maximum 12 months period for hedges of forecasted sales.

Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty will not meet its obligations under a financial instrument or customer contract, leading to a financial loss. Gokaldas Exports Limited manages customer credit risk through established policies, procedures, and control, including impairment analysis for major customers.

Liquidity risk refers to the risk that Gokaldas Exports Limited cannot meet its financial obligations. The company manages this risk by maintaining sufficient liquidity, utilizing working capital lines from various banks, and investing surplus funds in low-risk assets.

Mr. Prabhat Kumar Singh is a director at Gokaldas Exports Limited with four decades of experience in the apparel and textile sector. He has expertise in setting up apparel manufacturing units, formulating recommendations to the Government on import-export policy, arranging joint ventures, and organizing fairs and exhibitions. He has held leadership positions in the textile industry and industry bodies like the Apparel Export Promotion Council (AEPC). He played a significant role in interfacing with the industry and various regulatory authorities, including project implementation under Government schemes, modernization, technology and infrastructure upgradation for textiles, and funding support. He was instrumental in setting up the new apparel manufacturing plant in Madhya Pradesh (Gokaldas Exports Acharpura Private Limited) and Tamil Nadu (Sri Susamyuta Knits Private Limited). He graduated from Banaras Hindu University and completed his MBA from XLRI, Jamshedpur. He also holds a Diploma in International Marketing from Buckinghamshire College (UK). The text discusses the reappointment of Mr. Prabhat Kumar Singh, who is 72 years old, as it requires shareholder approval via a special resolution according to Section 196 (3) of the Companies Act, 2013.

Mr. Mathew Cyriac holds a Bachelor Degree in Engineering and an MBA from the Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore. He was awarded the IIMB Gold Medal for graduating at the top of his MBA class. Mr. Mathew Cyriac is the Chairman and Whole-Time Director of Florintree Advisors Private Limited. He was a Senior Managing Director at The Blackstone Group and has served as Co-Head of Private Equity at Blackstone Advisors India Private Limited till February 2017. He has rich experience in Investment Banking and served at Bank of America and Tata Motors, some of the leading institutions in India. He also has served as Head Corporate Development Strategy of iGate Global Solutions Limited.
